description:
In this activity, you will explore data showing how humans have changed Earth’s land. Suitable agricultural land is a limited resource, and its distribution is affected by many factors, including human development and the availability of other limited resources.

Thumbnail credit: USDA, Economic Research Service
name: Using the land
notes: Credit for thumbnail image: USDA, Economic Research Service

interactives.credit: Ellis E et al. PNAS 2013; Used Planet, a Global History. Figure 1

embeddables.content:
Land use refers to the ways that humans use the land. Land use involves modifying and managing the natural environment.

The modifications include fields, pastures, industrial developments, residential developments, golf courses, ski areas, parks, and roads.

Land use management practices vary around the world. How the land is used can affect the quality and availability of natural resources, such as water, soil, nutrients, plants, and animals. 

The maps show how humans have changed the land over the past 8,000 years. 

The HYDE model assumes that land use is stable over time, while the KK10 model assumes that land use intensifies over time. Both models show the time of first significant use, the percent recovery from peak use, and the locations of dense settlements in the year 2000.

embeddables.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddables.prompt: Which area of the world has been intensively used for the longest period of time?

pages.name: For what do we use the land?

interactives.caption: A Northern Virginia housing development encroaches on farmland. Population growth and relocation is threatening rural environments across the world.

embeddables.content:
Land is a finite resource on Earth. Around the world, people have tried to create more land by filling in shallow bodies of water, but in the end, there is only so much land.

What is that land used for?

There are human uses – land for living on, land for producing food, land for recreation – and there are natural users as well. Residents of the natural ecosystems need land for their own life cycles.

The photograph shows a housing development encroaching on farmland. Increasingly, farmland has been converted into residential and commercial purposes.

embeddables.prompt: Why do you think houses are being built on farmland?

embeddables.content:
Land can be managed in several different ways. Humans modify the land for their own purposes, but it is also important to consider the non-human users of the land – native plants and animals.

In addition to providing recreation opportunities, forests and other open parcels of land provide valuable services, including cleaning the air, filtering and holding water, producing oxygen, and storing carbon dioxide.

The photo shows Nantahala National Forest in North Carolina.

embeddables.prompt:
What are the consequences of turning forested land into farm land?
List two positive and two negative effects of turning forest land into farm land.

What are the consequences of turning forested land into residential land?
List two positive and two negative effects of turning forest land into residential land.

pages.name: Land use changes in the US

interactives.caption: Change in land use in the United States, 1949-2007

embeddables.content:
There are few habitats on Earth that have not been modified by humans. One very important land use is agriculture. 

The graph shows land uses in the United States from 1949 to 2007.

embeddables.prompt: Describe the change in the amount of agricultural land in the United States from 1949 to 2007.
Why do you think the land use changed this way?

interactives.credit: Center for Sustainability and the Global Environment, University of Wisconsin, Madison

embeddables.content:
Sustainable agriculture needs:

  • fertile soils
  • adequate precipitation
  • good growing temperatures
The map shows the suitability of areas around the world for sustainable agriculture.

embeddables.name: Multiple Choice Question element
embeddables.prompt: Is agricultural land evenly distributed around the world?
What areas of the world are most suitable for agriculture?

pages.name: Farmland in the path of development

embeddables.content:
All land is not equally useful for all purposes. It takes high quality soil conditions to make high quality farmland. 

Some areas are too dry to farm without irrigation. Poor soils need to be fertilized heavily to reach the same production levels as high-quality soils.

The map shows the United States by land type and use. Less than 20% of land in the United States is high quality farmland. The map shows the loss of farmland to development. 

The map shows high quality farmland with red and green shading. Some of these high quality farmlands have been developed for purposes other than farming (red shading).

  • Consider the completeness of the evidence, biases in the evidence, and changes that could affect the trends over time.

pages.name: Limited resources
pages.text:
The human population has increased greatly. The graph shows the population increase by continent. 

www.theglobaleducationproject.org

However, the land that's suitable for agriculture hasn't grown. Increasingly, productive farmland is being turned into residential land. Even so, food production has mostly kept pace with population growth. In some areas of the world, agricultural production has greatly exceeded population growth.

Changes in farming practices have allowed the world's farmers to produce enough food to feed the growing population. Innovations in chemistry and biology, as well as careful management of the land, have brought us this far. 

But will new innovations ensure that there will be enough food in the future?
